_**Bajirao Mastani**_ is a 2015 Indian [epic](/wiki/Epic_film "Epic film")
[historical romance](/wiki/Historical_romance "Historical romance") film
directed by [Sanjay Leela Bhansali](/wiki/Sanjay_Leela_Bhansali "Sanjay Leela
Bhansali"), who also composed its
[soundtrack](/wiki/Bajirao_Mastani_\(soundtrack\) "Bajirao Mastani
\(soundtrack\)"). The film was jointly produced by Bhansali and [Eros
International](/wiki/Eros_International "Eros International")'s Kishore Lulla;
it stars [Ranveer Singh](/wiki/Ranveer_Singh "Ranveer Singh"), [Deepika
Padukone](/wiki/Deepika_Padukone "Deepika Padukone") and [Priyanka
Chopra](/wiki/Priyanka_Chopra "Priyanka Chopra"). The supporting cast includes
[Tanvi Azmi](/wiki/Tanvi_Azmi "Tanvi Azmi"), [Vaibhav
Tatwawaadi](/wiki/Vaibhav_Tatwawaadi "Vaibhav Tatwawaadi") and [Milind
Soman](/wiki/Milind_Soman "Milind Soman"). Based on the
[Marathi](/wiki/Marathi_language "Marathi language") novel _Raau_ by [Nagnath
S. Inamdar](/wiki/Nagnath_S._Inamdar "Nagnath S. Inamdar"), _Bajirao Mastani_
narrates the story of the [Maratha](/wiki/Maratha "Maratha")
_[Peshwa](/wiki/Peshwa "Peshwa")_ [Bajirao I](/wiki/Bajirao_I "Bajirao I")
(1700–1740 AD) and his second wife [Mastani](/wiki/Mastani "Mastani").

Conceived as early as the 1990s, Bhansali announced the film in 2003 but
production was delayed several times due to its changing cast. _Bajirao
Mastani_ , a passion project for Bhansali, spent the next eleven years in
[development hell](/wiki/Development_hell "Development hell") before being
revived in 2014. Extensive research was done before moving into [pre-
production](/wiki/Pre-production "Pre-production"), which required the
creation of twenty-two highly detailed sets, and numerous costumes and props
to strengthen its opulence and high production value. [Principal
photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography") took place
on sets constructed in [Film City](/wiki/Film_City "Film City"), with some
portions being filmed on location. [Visual effects](/wiki/Visual_effects
"Visual effects") and [CGI](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-
generated imagery") were used in [post-production](/wiki/Post-production
"Post-production") to enhance a number of scenes.

The film was released on 18 December 2015 to positive reviews, with praise
directed towards Bhansali's direction, various technical achievements and the
performances of the cast. _Bajirao Mastani_ has also been noted for its scale,
grandeur and attention to detail. With a budget of ₹145 crores, including
marketing and advertisements, it is one of the [most expensive Hindi
films](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_Indian_films "List of most expensive
Indian films"). It has grossed over ₹356 crores at the box office, becoming a
major commercial success and one of the [highest-grossing Indian
films](/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_Indian_films "List of highest-grossing
Indian films") of all time.

Recipient of [several
accolades](/wiki/List_of_accolades_received_by_Bajirao_Mastani "List of
accolades received by Bajirao Mastani"), _Bajirao Mastani_ won seven [National
Film Awards](/wiki/National_Film_Awards "National Film Awards"), including
[Best Direction](/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Direction "National Film
Award for Best Direction") and [Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "National Film
Award for Best Supporting Actress") for Azmi. The film received a leading
fourteen nominations at the [61st Filmfare Awards](/wiki/61st_Filmfare_Awards
"61st Filmfare Awards") and won nine awards, including [Best
Film](/wiki/Filmfare_Award_for_Best_Film "Filmfare Award for Best Film"),
[Best Director](/wiki/Filmfare_Award_for_Best_Director "Filmfare Award for
Best Director") for Bhansali, [Best Actor](/wiki/Filmfare_Award_for_Best_Actor
"Filmfare Award for Best Actor") for Singh, and [Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/Filmfare_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "Filmfare Award for
Best Supporting Actress") for Chopra.

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Plot")]

In the early 18th century, the court of [Maratha](/wiki/Maratha_Empire
"Maratha Empire") king [Chhatrapati Shahu](/wiki/Chhatrapati_Shahu
"Chhatrapati Shahu") needs a new _[Peshwa](/wiki/Peshwa "Peshwa")_ , the
equivalent of a modern-day prime minister. In spite of Shripad Rao's self-
nomination as the _Peshwa_ , Ambaji Pant nominates a young
[Bajirao](/wiki/Bajirao_I "Bajirao I"). To test his spiritual wisdom and
knowledge of weaponry, Shripad challenges Bajirao to split a peacock feather
with an arrow. Bajirao succeeds and is given the title of _Peshwa_. Ten years
later, his wife [Kashibai](/wiki/Kashibai "Kashibai") is visited by her
widowed friend Bhanu, whose husband was accused of spying and was ordered to
be executed by Bajirao. She predicts that just as she longs for her husband,
Kashibai will yearn for Bajirao.

While travelling to [Sironja](/wiki/Sironj "Sironj"), an emissary from
[Bundelkhand](/wiki/Bundelkhand "Bundelkhand") enters Bajirao's tent and
requests his help to fight invaders. She reveals herself to be
[Mastani](/wiki/Mastani "Mastani"), the daughter of the Hindu
[Rajput](/wiki/Rajput "Rajput") king [Chhatrasal](/wiki/Chhatrasal
"Chhatrasal") and his [Persian](/wiki/Persian_people "Persian people") Muslim
consort Ruhani Bai. Impressed by her skills as a warrior, Bajirao assists her
with his army and defeats the invaders. Chhatrasal is overjoyed and insists
Bajirao spend [Holi](/wiki/Holi "Holi") with them in Bundelkhand. Mastani and
Bajirao fall in love with each other and he gives her his dagger, unaware it
is a symbol of marriage among the Bundelkhand Rajputs. Bajirao departs for
[Pune](/wiki/Pune "Pune"), where Kashibai greets him with a tour of their
newly-built [Shaniwar Wada](/wiki/Shaniwar_Wada "Shaniwar Wada") and shows him
the [Aaina Mahal](/wiki/Aina_Mahal "Aina Mahal") (hall of mirrors), which
allows her to see him from her room.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Peshwa_Baji_Rao_I_riding_horse.jpg/153px-
Peshwa_Baji_Rao_I_riding_horse.jpg)](/wiki/File:Peshwa_Baji_Rao_I_riding_horse.jpg)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Mastani_28tt13.jpg/150px-
Mastani_28tt13.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mastani_28tt13.jpg)

A painting of Baji Rao I _(left)_ and Mastani _(right)_

Determined to pursue her love, Mastani arrives in Pune but is treated harshly
by Bajirao's mother Radhabai and accommodated in the palace for
[courtesans](/wiki/Courtesan "Courtesan"). Mastani tolerates this insult and
appears to dance before Bajirao. Radhabai scornfully offers her the occupation
of a royal dancer but refuses to accept her as a daughter-in-law. Mastani
travels to the Chhatrapati Shahu and expresses her desire to be with Bajirao,
then leaves to wait for him at a ruin across a river. During a storm, Bajirao
crosses the river and chides Mastani's persistence, reminding her he is
already married and that his court will never respect her if she is in a
relationship with him. She agrees, despite his warning, and he declares
Mastani his second wife.

The Marathas prepare to attack [Delhi](/wiki/Delhi "Delhi"), the capital of
the [Mughal Empire](/wiki/Mughal_Empire "Mughal Empire"), but must first
ensure the [Nizam of Hyderabad](/wiki/Nizam_of_Hyderabad "Nizam of
Hyderabad"), the Muslim ruler of [Hyderabad State](/wiki/Hyderabad_State
"Hyderabad State"), will not attack them during their assault. Bajirao leaves
to confront the Nizam, [Qamar ud-Din Khan](/wiki/Qamar-ud-din_Khan,_Asif_Jah_I
"Qamar-ud-din Khan, Asif Jah I"), and returns successful. In the Aaina Mahal,
Kashibai, who is pregnant, sees Bajirao embracing Mastani, who is also
expecting, and leaves for her mother's home. She returns to joyous
celebrations months later with her newborn son, who is named
[Raghunath](/wiki/Raghunathrao "Raghunathrao"). Mastani also gives birth to a
son, whom Mastani and Bajirao name Krishna Rao. After the head
[Brahmin](/wiki/Brahmin "Brahmin") priest Krishna Bhatt refuses to conduct the
_naamkaran_ (the Hindu naming ceremony) on the grounds that Krishna Rao is
illegitimate, Bajirao renames his son [Shamsher
Bahadur](/wiki/Shamsher_Bahadur "Shamsher Bahadur"). A few years later,
Kashibai and Bajirao's eldest son [Balaji Baji Rao](/wiki/Balaji_Baji_Rao
"Balaji Baji Rao"), also known as Nana Saheb, returns from
[Satara](/wiki/Satara_\(city\) "Satara \(city\)") and expresses his hatred of
Mastani for disrupting his mother's marriage.

Shiva Bhatt, a Brahmin priest, informs Kashibai of a plan to murder Mastani
and her son during a festival. Kashibai relays this news to Bajirao, who
rescues both of them. Krishna Bhatt kills Shiva Bhatt, enraging Bajirao. To
keep Mastani's safe and to grant her a royal home, Bajirao builds the Mastani
Mahal for her. Bajirao, however, is heartbroken due to the betrayal of his
mother Radhabai and his brother [Chimaji Appa](/wiki/Chimaji_Appa "Chimaji
Appa"). Meanwhile, Pant tells Bajirao he must defeat [Nasir
Jung](/wiki/Nasir_Jung "Nasir Jung"), the vengeful son of the Nizam. Bajirao
says that although he loves Mastani, his life and allegiance is always to his
cause and he leaves for the battlefield. Before leaving, he meets Kashibai in
deference to a tradition that the wife sent her husband off into battle.
Kashibai tells Bajirao he has broken her heart and compares their love with
that of [Krishna](/wiki/Krishna "Krishna") and [Rukmini](/wiki/Rukmini
"Rukmini"). Kashibai orders him never to enter her chamber again, and Bajirao
accepts and leaves.

After Bajirao leaves for battle, Radhabai and Nana Saheb imprison Mastani and
Shamsher Bahadur. After Bajirao receives the news, he single-handedly defeats
Nasir Jung's army in his rage but collapses from his injuries. At his
deathbed, Kashibai sends a letter pleading with Radhabai to release Mastani so
Bajirao can recover, but Nana Saheb burns the letter and refuses to release
Mastani. Bajirao, delirious due to his sickness, dies from the trauma of his
hallucinations; at the same time Mastani dies in captivity. The ill-fated
lovers are shown to be united in death.

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

[![A photograph of Sanjay Leela Bhansali looking towards the
camera](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Sanjay_Leela_Bhansali2.jpg/220px-
Sanjay_Leela_Bhansali2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sanjay_Leela_Bhansali2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sanjay_Leela_Bhansali2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Sanjay Leela Bhansali](/wiki/Sanjay_Leela_Bhansali "Sanjay Leela Bhansali")
(_pictured in 2011_) had been longing to make the film for over a decade.

[Sanjay Leela Bhansali](/wiki/Sanjay_Leela_Bhansali "Sanjay Leela Bhansali")
had conceived the historical romance about Maratha Peshwa
[Bajirao](/wiki/Baji_Rao_I "Baji Rao I") and his second wife Mastani even
before he had directed his first feature _[Khamoshi: The
Musical](/wiki/Khamoshi:_The_Musical "Khamoshi: The Musical")_ in 1996.[4]
Several other directors such as [Muzaffar Ali](/wiki/Muzaffar_Ali "Muzaffar
Ali"), [Manmohan Desai](/wiki/Manmohan_Desai "Manmohan Desai") and [Kamal
Amrohi](/wiki/Kamal_Amrohi "Kamal Amrohi") had tried to make a film about the
two historical figures but they were never made.[5] Bhansali had intended to
make _Bajirao Mastani_ after the release of
_[Devdas](/wiki/Devdas_\(2002_Hindi_film\) "Devdas \(2002 Hindi film\)")_
(2002) and had officially announced it in 2003, with filming scheduled to
begin in May 2004.[6] The film, however, was shelved indefinitely. Reports
about a possible revival had made headlines ever since; Bhansali had planned
to revive it every other year but the project never came to fruition.[7] In an
interview with _[The Telegraph](/wiki/The_Telegraph_\(Calcutta\) "The
Telegraph \(Calcutta\)")_ , Bhansali spoke about his intention to make
_Bajirao Mastani_ after finishing every film he made in-between, saying "I
kept trying to revive it over and over again, but if there is one thing that
filmmaking has taught me, it's that every film has its own destiny. And I
strongly believe that the souls of ... Bajirao, Mastani and Kashibai wanted us
to make this film only now."[5] In the process, the film became a passion
project for him.[5]

After spending eleven years in [development hell](/wiki/Development_hell
"Development hell"), Bhansali revived the project in 2014; the film was
reported to be an adaptation of the Marathi-language novel _Raau_ (1976) by
[Nagnath S. Inamdar](/wiki/Nagnath_S._Inamdar "Nagnath S. Inamdar").[4] After
the project was shelved, Bhansali said he struggled to put the film together
and that he considered the project impossible to made. Nevertheless, he clung
to his ambition to make the film someday, saying, "there is magic to it".[5]
Some film industry professionals believed it would never be made, calling it
"jinxed".[8] Bhansali always believed in the project, assuring himself the
script was so powerful he had to make it one day.[8] He told _The Telegraph_ ,
"Honestly, I want very few things in life ... so I know that I am resilient
enough to get them all! Deep down, I kept asking for the universe to let me
make this film. When you dream very genuinely, then I believe you also get the
power to fulfill it. In pursuing _Bajirao Mastani_ , I have been resilient and
very focused. I have sacrificed a lot of things".[5]

Primarily known for making romantic dramas, Bhansali was intrigued about the
romance between "two people who defied everything, just to be in love with
each other", and was excited to tell a 200-year-old story.[5] He wanted to
show the relationship between Bajirao and Mastani because it was rarely
depicted in history books, and little was known about it.[5] He had long
admired the Maratha backdrop and the different religions of the
protagonists—Bajirao was Hindu and Mastani was Muslim—which further drove his
interest towards knowing more and telling the story.[5] He saw it as a chance
to comment on religion and love, saying, "In those times, people were offended
by the same things that offend them today. Through this film, I want to show
that love is the greatest religion."[5]

Prakash R. Kapadia wrote the screenplay.[9] The makers acquired the rights of
the novel and worked with historian [Ninad Bedekar](/wiki/Ninad_Bedekar "Ninad
Bedekar"). Kapadia said writing the screenplay was a difficult task and a huge
responsibility considering the historical context.[9] Kapadia and Bhansali had
consistently worked on the script since its conception, refining several
aspects of the film.[9] Considering the script was written twelve years
before, several changes were made to it, such as the decreasing the length and
increasing the pace to suit the modern audiences.[9] Although adapted from the
novel, the romance between the film's protagonists has not been well
documented in history books or archives and several versions of the story
exist. Many cinematic liberties were taken to build drama and highlight
incidents.[5]

### Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Casting")]

Bhansali originally wanted to repeat his _[Hum Dil De Chuke
Sanam](/wiki/Hum_Dil_De_Chuke_Sanam "Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam")_ (1999) pairing
of [Salman Khan](/wiki/Salman_Khan "Salman Khan") with [Aishwarya
Rai](/wiki/Aishwarya_Rai "Aishwarya Rai") for the eponymous roles, but could
not cast them together after their highly publicised break-up.[10] Khan then
tried to suggest his then-girlfriend [Katrina Kaif](/wiki/Katrina_Kaif
"Katrina Kaif") for the role of Mastani but things did not materialise.[11]
When the film was finally announced in 2003, Bhansali had cast Khan and
[Kareena Kapoor](/wiki/Kareena_Kapoor "Kareena Kapoor") in the titular roles,
with [Rani Mukerji](/wiki/Rani_Mukerji "Rani Mukerji") playing Baji Rao's
first wife Kashibai.[6] However, the idea was scrapped when Khan and Kapoor
signed other films together. Bhansali wanted to be the first director to
showcase their pairing. Hence, the film was shelved and Bhansali went on to
direct other films.[10]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Ranvir%2C_Dipika_at_the_press_conference_of_%E2%80%98Bajirao_Mastani%E2%80%99.jpg/250px-
Ranvir%2C_Dipika_at_the_press_conference_of_%E2%80%98Bajirao_Mastani%E2%80%99.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ranvir,_Dipika_at_the_press_conference_of_%E2%80%98Bajirao_Mastani%E2%80%99.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ranvir,_Dipika_at_the_press_conference_of_%E2%80%98Bajirao_Mastani%E2%80%99.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Ranveer Singh](/wiki/Ranveer_Singh "Ranveer Singh") _(left)_ and [Deepika
Padukone](/wiki/Deepika_Padukone "Deepika Padukone") _(right)_ were cast to
play the titular roles.

Over the following ten years, media speculation about the production and
casting of _Bajirao Mastani_ continued.[12] After the film was revived in
2014, reports of [Ajay Devgn](/wiki/Ajay_Devgn "Ajay Devgn") and [Deepika
Padukone](/wiki/Deepika_Padukone "Deepika Padukone") being approached for the
film made headlines in February.[13] Devgn dropped out of the film, however,
due to differences with Bhansali about several terms of his contract, such as
dates and remuneration.[14] The next month, it was reported that [Ranveer
Singh](/wiki/Ranveer_Singh "Ranveer Singh") was in talks to play Bajirao.[15]
The same month, reports suggested [Priyanka Chopra](/wiki/Priyanka_Chopra
"Priyanka Chopra") was cast to play Kashibai, Bajirao's first wife.[16] In
July 2014, it was officially confirmed that Singh, Padukone and Chopra were
finalised to play the principal roles.[17]

Chopra was the first actor to be cast in the film; Bhansali wanted Kashibai to
be cast first, only after which he could decide who to cast for the title
roles.[18][_[unreliable source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources
"Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources")_][19] Bhansali, who produced Chopra-
starrer _[Mary Kom](/wiki/Mary_Kom_\(film\) "Mary Kom \(film\)")_ (2014), went
on to that film's set in [Manali](/wiki/Manali,_Himachal_Pradesh "Manali,
Himachal Pradesh") to narrate it with the writer Prakash Kapadia; Bhansali was
adamant in his choice of Chopra, who recalled, "The rest of the film hadn't
been cast yet. My picture would be there and the pictures for Bajirao and
Mastani would keep changing."[18][20]

[Milind Soman](/wiki/Milind_Soman "Milind Soman") joined the cast in the late
August 2014.[21] In late September 2014, it was confirmed that [Tanvi
Azmi](/wiki/Tanvi_Azmi "Tanvi Azmi") was cast for the role of Bajirao's mother
Radhabai; [Shabana Azmi](/wiki/Shabana_Azmi "Shabana Azmi"), [Dimple
Kapadia](/wiki/Dimple_Kapadia "Dimple Kapadia"), and [Supriya
Pathak](/wiki/Supriya_Pathak "Supriya Pathak") had also been considered for
the role.[22] The following month, [Aditya Pancholi](/wiki/Aditya_Pancholi
"Aditya Pancholi") joined the cast as an antagonist.[23] In November 2014, the
casting of Bajirao's sisters were finalised; Sukhada Khandkekar was ast as
Anubai and [Anuja Gokhale](/wiki/Anuja_Gokhale "Anuja Gokhale") as
Bhiubai.[24] The following month, [Mahesh Manjrekar](/wiki/Mahesh_Manjrekar
"Mahesh Manjrekar") was cast to play Maratha Emperor Chhattrapati Shahu.[25]
It was announced in January 2015 that [Vaibhav
Tatwawaadi](/wiki/Vaibhav_Tatwawaadi "Vaibhav Tatwawaadi") was chosen to play
Bajirao's younger brother Chimaji Appa.[26] [Irrfan Khan](/wiki/Irrfan_Khan
"Irrfan Khan") was cast as the film's narrator.[3]

All of the actors had to undergo training before filming began; Singh and
Padukone learned sword-fighting, horse-riding and the ancient Indian martial
art [Kalaripayattu](/wiki/Kalaripayattu "Kalaripayattu").[27][28] Singh was
also required to learn Marathi and shave his head for the part, whereas
Padukone had to take [Kathak](/wiki/Kathak "Kathak") dance lessons.[27][29] In
preparation for her role of Kashibai, Chopra had 15 days of language training
in the Peshwai Marathi dialect spoken during the time of the ascension of the
Peshwas to perfect the accent.[30] Azmi shaved her head completely for her
role.[31]

Singh has described his character as a "true Maratha", saying, "The deeper I
get into it the more I realise what a great man he was. It is a great honour
to be selected to play this character."[32] He has said he always wanted to
transform himself into a character and playing Bajirao gave him that scope,
which he said was "draining and tiring in every way".[33] For portraying
Bajirao, Singh's preparations required him to isolate himself from his own
being and living like Bajirao. He instructed the crew members to address him
as Bajirao, which helped him to remain in his character.[33] Singh would not
respond to people who used his real name. He said, "It takes a lot of work and
effort to be different from whom I am, and two hours to get ready, complete
with makeup and the heavy costumes. After all this, if someone just tells me,
Ranveer, your shot is ready! all that goes to waste."[33] Padukone found her
character to be very relatable, saying, "She was so brave, strong, determined
and yet fragile and vulnerable".[34] She was also inspired by her character
and found playing the role challenging; it was physically demanding and
required a lot of dancing.[34] Padukone said the character had different
layers; "One minute she goes on the battlefield, the next minute she's
romancing him".[34] Chopra was drawn towards the film because of her character
which she thought was "very heart-breaking".[18] She said playing Kashibai was
"emotionally difficult" and a complete contrast to the strong women she has
portrayed in most of her films.[35] She described her character as someone who
is "heartbroken, a silent sufferer, dignified, resilient, can't take charge of
her life, goes with whatever life throws her way. Just grace under fire."[35]

### Pre-
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Pre-production")]

Considering its scale, the film required detailed and extravagant pre-
production work, which required extensive research and planning. Saloni
Dhatrak, Sriram Iyengar and Sujeet Sawant worked as [production
designers](/wiki/Production_designer "Production designer") on the film.[36]
Iyengar and Sawant had heard about the film while working on another film,
when it was first announced. Having never met Bhansali, they started
researching on their own by visiting Pune and [Satara](/wiki/Satara_\(city\)
"Satara \(city\)") and learnt about Maratha architecture.[36] When the film
was shelved, they continued to research and formed a portfolio, hoping to
approach other filmmakers for work. Several years later, when they heard about
the revival, they met Bhansali, who was impresses by their research and
presentation.[36][37] Bhansali wanted more research on [Mughals](/wiki/Mughals
"Mughals"); he engaged Dhatrak, who joined Iyengar and Sawant.[36] Bhansali
then shared the script with the art directors and described his vision and the
scale of the production.[38] Pre-production work started as early as February
2014, continued as the shoot progressed and lasted until the filming was
complete in October 2015; it lasted nineteen months.[37] Before pre-production
work started, the art directors discussed with Bhansali about how much of the
film would be filmed on set and outdoor locations, giving them an idea to how
many sets they needed to create. Once the number of sets and location shots
was decided, the production moved forward.[38]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG/300px-
Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG)](/wiki/File:Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Shaniwarwada_gate.JPG "Enlarge")

The set for [Shaniwar Wada](/wiki/Shaniwar_Wada "Shaniwar Wada") was the
biggest set created for the film.

Along with the art directors, nineteen art assistant directors, including
architects, designers, sketch artists and props artists, were involved.[37]
Twenty-two sets were created in [Film City](/wiki/Film_City "Film City")
following a flow chart that included around 960 sketches and countless
layouts. The two biggest sets were the exact replicas of [Shaniwar
Wada](/wiki/Shaniwar_Wada "Shaniwar Wada") and the Aaina Mahal, both of which
were "high on grandeur and intricacy".[37] The Shaniwar Wada set was the
biggest set they had constructed; it took 45,000 planks and 600 workers a day
to erect.[36] It was constructed on Sunil Maidan, one of the biggest open
spaces in Film City and took forty-five days to build.[37] Kashibai's room was
the first set to be constructed, which was approved after navigating through
twenty-five designs.[37] The art directors did architectural research from
Pune, [Nasik](/wiki/Nasik "Nasik") and Satara, studying fortifications, baston
walls and city gates to understand the interior and exterior designs of the
ancient period and incorporated those ideas into building Kashibai's villa.
Lotus motifs on mud-clad walls and handmade textures were used to give the set
a realistic appearance.[37]

Aina Mahal took 4,500 planks, with a hundred workers per day. The set was
given a lotus-like design, with walls, ceiling and floor made out of handmade
mud embedded with sparkling mirror designs.[37][39] The replica of Aina Mahal
was constructed in forty days, with more than 30,000 square feet of mirrors.
More than 700 design stencils were used to decorate the hall.[39] Although the
mirror hall was a Mughal concept, the art directors designed it to look like
Maratha architecture. Mastani Mahal was built as an amalgamation of Rajput and
Maratha architecture.[37] The exterior of Mastani Mahal was built as a part of
Shaniwar Wada, whereas the interiors of were built on separate sets consisting
of a courtyard and bedroom. Mastani's room in Bundelkhand was crafted using a
mix of Persian, Mughal and Rajput motifs and architecture.[37]

All of the sets were furnished with opulent objects and props to give the
interiors a feel of the ancient [Maratha empire](/wiki/Maratha_empire "Maratha
empire"). Only earthen diyas and torches were used to light the sets.[37]
Silken saris were used, with bedsheets and hand-painted walls with 18th
century motifs added.[39] Craftsmen were hired to recreate 18th-century
textures, fabrics, weaponry, jewellery and furniture. Almost 30,000 oil lamps
were made for the film and 500 suits of armour were designed for the war
scenes.[39] There were also headgear and boots worn in that period. The armour
and headgear weighed between ten-twenty kilos and two kilos, respectively.[39]
The team also designed props including different types of tents, lighting
props, and elephant and horse decors for the war sequences. The props were
made in Mumbai and had to be taken to Rajasthan, the outdoor location.[37]

### Costumes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Costumes")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Ravi_Varma-
Princess_Damayanthi_talking_with_Royal_Swan_about_Nala.jpg/200px-Ravi_Varma-
Princess_Damayanthi_talking_with_Royal_Swan_about_Nala.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ravi_Varma-
Princess_Damayanthi_talking_with_Royal_Swan_about_Nala.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ravi_Varma-
Princess_Damayanthi_talking_with_Royal_Swan_about_Nala.jpg "Enlarge")

The paintings of [Raja Ravi Varma](/wiki/Raja_Ravi_Varma "Raja Ravi Varma")
was used as an inspiration for creating Kashibai's look

The film's costumes were designed by Anju Modi and Maxima Basu.[40] Modi
designed clothes for the three lead characters and Basu designed for the
supporting cast. The costumes for extras and war extras were done by Ajay and
Chandrakant, respectively.[40] Bhansali had detailed script-reading sessions
with the designers to help them understand the characters, their emotions and
personalities, which would mirror the costumes and the grandeur of the 18th
century.[41] Basu started her research by visiting several ancient monuments
such as the [Chowmahalla Palace](/wiki/Chowmahalla_Palace "Chowmahalla
Palace"), [Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu
Sangrahalaya](/wiki/Chhatrapati_Shivaji_Maharaj_Vastu_Sangrahalaya
"Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya"), [Salar Jung
Museum](/wiki/Salar_Jung_Museum "Salar Jung Museum") and
[Ajanta](/wiki/Ajanta_Caves "Ajanta Caves")-[Ellora](/wiki/Ellora_Caves
"Ellora Caves") caves, which gave her some perspective of ancient Maharastrian
culture.[41] She also travelled to cities such as [Indore](/wiki/Indore
"Indore"), [Chanderi](/wiki/Chanderi "Chanderi"), [Paithan](/wiki/Paithan
"Paithan") and [Maheshwar](/wiki/Maheshwar "Maheshwar") to gather more
knowledge about the history of clothing and textiles.[42]

About 300 costumes were designed for the three leads alone.[39] Real
[zari](/wiki/Zari "Zari") and [goldwires](/wiki/Goldwire "Goldwire") were used
to weave the costumes.[41] Since no pictures of Kashibai existed, the
paintings of [Raja Ravi Varma](/wiki/Raja_Ravi_Varma "Raja Ravi Varma") were
used as a reference for designing her looks and costumes.[39] Modi had
designed eighty [nauvari or nine-yard saris](/wiki/Kasta_sari "Kasta sari")
with bright colours such as yellows, hot pink, emerald green and purple,
inspired from the Raja Ravi Varma paintings, for Chopra.[42] The custom-made
nine-yard saris were weaved by craftsmen from [Maheshwar](/wiki/Maheshwar
"Maheshwar"), [Chander](/wiki/Chander "Chander") and [Varanasi](/wiki/Varanasi
"Varanasi"); they were made a little lighter than usual to avoid making Chopra
Priyanka look large on screen.[43][44] For making the saris, fabrics such as
[Mul-Mul](/wiki/Mul-Mul "Mul-Mul"), silk, muslin, [khadi](/wiki/Khadi "Khadi")
and [chanderis](/wiki/Chanderi "Chanderi") worn in that period were
designed.[39][42] For one song sequence featuring Chopra, Modi had created six
sets of the same sari.[43]

Peshwas used to wear _[Dhotis](/wiki/Dhoti "Dhoti")_ ,
_[Jamas](/wiki/Jama_\(coat\) "Jama \(coat\)")_ and _[Angarkhas](/wiki/Angarkha
"Angarkha")_ with a large flare in that period, so it was eminent for
Bajirao's character.[41][43] A wide palette of solid colours, such as white
and cream, were used for the sombre and emotional scenes whereas red, orange,
blue and deep purple were used for the celebratory scenes.[44] For designing
the Bajirao's armour, [chain mail](/wiki/Chain_Mail_Armor "Chain Mail Armor"),
khaki and [steel grey](/wiki/Steel_grey "Steel grey") were employed.[44] A
[dandpatta](/wiki/Pata_\(sword\) "Pata \(sword\)") sword was also made for
him.[39] For Mastani, Modi used a mix of Persian and Muslim clothing of
muslin, khadi and thin Chanderi fabrics, with mukaish and
[zardosi](/wiki/Zardozi "Zardozi") hand embroidery to depict her half-Muslim
heritage.[41][42] Padukone was predominantly given [shararas](/wiki/Sharara
"Sharara") and its derivatives such trailing shararas, shararas with less
flare and crinkled shararas made of [chiffon](/wiki/Chiffon_\(fabric\)
"Chiffon \(fabric\)"). She was given a [lehenga](/wiki/Lehenga "Lehenga") for
just one scene.[41] She was also given Odhnis, [dupattas](/wiki/Dupatta
"Dupatta"), [veils](/wiki/Veil "Veil"), floor-skimming
[anarkalis](/wiki/Anarkali_Salwar_Suit "Anarkali Salwar Suit") and angrakhas
paired with [Farshi pajamas](/wiki/Farshi_Pajama "Farshi Pajama").[45][43]
Softer colours with Persian influences such as shades of powder blue, mint
green, pale yellow, aqua blue, powder pink and other typical porcelain colours
were used for her clothes.[42][44] A [turban](/wiki/Turban "Turban")
embellished with jewellery such as uncut diamonds and pearls was designed.[41]
For one of the Mastani costumes, Modu designed a five-layered outfit
consisting of an angrakha jacket, a woven [leheria](/wiki/Leheria "Leheria")
dupatta, sharara and inner [kurti](/wiki/Kurta "Kurta").[45]

Expensive and real jewellery was used in the film.[42] The designers created
the jewellery for each character.[45] Modi said they did not want to
compromise, so the best materials such as real Basra [pearls](/wiki/Pearls
"Pearls"), antique stones and [uncut diamonds](/wiki/Uncut_diamond "Uncut
diamond") were used to give the royal look needed for the characters.[45]
Traditional Marathi-style jewellery was used to style Kashibai, while for
Mastani [Nizami](/wiki/Nizam_\(title\) "Nizam \(title\)") and
[polki](/wiki/Polki "Polki") Jewellery was used.[42] Several Indian jewellery
designers, including PN Gadgil from Pune and Shri Hari Jewellers from Delhi,
were hired.[45] The costume and production designers also researched in
museums, art galleries, history books, paintings, palaces, temples and forts
to study the textiles, colour palettes and artwork of the ancient Maratha
Empire.[39][42]

### Principal
photography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Principal photography")]

Cinematographer [Sudeep Chatterjee](/wiki/Sudeep_Chatterjee "Sudeep
Chatterjee") shot the film using [Arri Alexa XT](/wiki/Arri_Alexa "Arri
Alexa") lenses.[46] Chatterjee had done extensive research before starting the
film.[46] [Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal
photography") began on 9 October 2014 with Chopra on the set in Film City,
[Mumbai](/wiki/Mumbai "Mumbai").[47][48][49][50] Later that month, Singh
joined the shoot.[51] Most of the film was shot on the highly detailed
sets.[50] In late November, Chopra fainted on the set due to exhaustion while
filming a scene that needed to be filmed ten times continuously. A doctor was
called and filming stopped for some time but she later resumed the shoot.[52]
Padukone joined the cast for two days during in late December 2014 and resumed
shooting in April 2015 after completing work for her other projects.[53][54]

Outdoor location filming began in February 2015 at [Amer Fort](/wiki/Amer_Fort
"Amer Fort") in [Jaipur](/wiki/Jaipur "Jaipur").[55] Crowd scenes were also
filmed there.[56] Singh fell off a horse while filming an action sequence and
was rushed to hospital; he was not seriously injured.[57] In May 2015,
however, he injured his shoulder and needed surgery; he resumed shooting after
break of two months.[58]

[![A photograph of Amer
Fort](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Amber_Fort_%28%E0%A4%86%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%B0_%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BE_%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%B2%E0%A4%BE_%29.jpg/300px-
Amber_Fort_%28%E0%A4%86%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%B0_%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BE_%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%B2%E0%A4%BE_%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amber_Fort_\(%E0%A4%86%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%B0_%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BE_%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%B2%E0%A4%BE_\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Amber_Fort_\(%E0%A4%86%E0%A4%AE%E0%A5%87%E0%A4%B0_%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BE_%E0%A4%95%E0%A4%BF%E0%A4%B2%E0%A4%BE_\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Some of the outdoor scenes were filmed at the [Amer Fort](/wiki/Amer_Fort
"Amer Fort")

Chopra resumed filming in the first week of April 2015 for a month.[59] While
working on _Bajirao Mastani_ , Chopra was simultaneously filming the American
television series _[Quantico](/wiki/Quantico_\(TV_series\) "Quantico \(TV
series\)")_ in [Montreal](/wiki/Montreal "Montreal"), requiring much back-and
forth travel.[60] She would act for _Bajirao Mastani_ at weekends and return
to Montreal on weekdays for her series, returning to India in the second week
of October to complete the final schedule.[61]

Before starting the film, the team discussed which parts of it had to be
filmed and which parts needed to be made using visual effects.[46] They
decided that only sequences that were considered difficult or impossible to
film would be created using visual effects in post production.[46] In one
sequence, it was impossible to control the movements of the 300–400 horses
standing at one position in a battle scene; this sequence was filmed with a
small number of horses and was later enhanced in post production.[46][62]

Sham Kaushal co-ordinated the action sequences for the war scenes.[39] Three
war sequences were filmed in [Rajasthan](/wiki/Rajasthan "Rajasthan"), [Madhya
Pradesh](/wiki/Madhya_Pradesh "Madhya Pradesh") and
[Maharashtra](/wiki/Maharashtra "Maharashtra"). Chatterjee found the war
sequences challenging and faced many difficulties while filming in the deserts
of Rajasthan. Wanting to break with norms, Bhansali wanted a night-time war
sequence; lighting a large, open field became very difficult and visibility
issues were inevitable. Bhansali wanted very clear images. Instead, they
decided to shoot these scenes in the morning, aiming for a twilight look.[46]
The main war scene featuring 800 extras, 500 horses and twenty-five elephants
was filmed over twenty days near Jaipur.[39] The extras would begin costuming,
which included beards for the Mughals, moustaches for the Marathas, armours,
helmets and uniforms, at 04:00 for the start of filming at 08:00.[39] After
finishing the shoot, the costumes would be washed in readiness for 04:00 the
following day. Kaushal has said extensive research was done before filming the
war sequences, and a rough graph was designed nine months before the
filming.[39] However, the entire sequence could not be filmed in one take on
location and was completed later in a studio in Film City, and was enhanced in
post production.[38]

[Ganesh Acharya](/wiki/Ganesh_Acharya "Ganesh Acharya"), [Remo
D'Souza](/wiki/Remo_D%27Souza "Remo D'Souza"), [Pony Verma](/wiki/Pony_Verma
"Pony Verma"), Shampa Gopikrishna and [Pandit Birju
Maharaj](/wiki/Pandit_Birju_Maharaj "Pandit Birju Maharaj") were the
choreographers for the film's song sequences.[3] Bhansali chose D'Souza, who
had only choreographed modern dance numbers at that time, to choreograph the
song "Pinga", which took weeks to complete. Chopra and Padukone had to
rehearse for several days before shooting.[63] The filming was challenging for
Chopra and Padukone; they had to shoot for the dance sequences multiple times
whenever the [diyas](/wiki/Diya_\(lamp\) "Diya \(lamp\)") and torches used to
light up the background would snuff.[64] The song was shot at night on an
open-air set decorated with diyas and torches, many of which would snuff out
while filming the song.[64] When it was suggested snuffed diyas should be
corrected in post production, Bhansali outright refused. More than twelve
people would run around the set with candles and oil to relight them.[64]

The sound recording was done on location. Sound designer Nihar Ranjan Samal
said they had to be careful that sounds of vehicles and honking did not make
their way into the recording. A number of scenes needed re-recording because
of some disturbance.[65] _Bajirao Mastani_ was shot in 217 days between
October 2014 and October 2015.[49]

### Post-
production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Post-production")]

The film contains 1,400 visual effects shots.[66] The company that worked on
the effects was [NY VFXWAALA](/wiki/NY_VFXWAALA "NY VFXWAALA"); this was the
biggest projects they had undertaken. [Prasad Sutar](/wiki/Prasad_Sutar
"Prasad Sutar") was the visual effects supervisor; the effects took eight
months and a team of sixty artists to create.[62] Although the film was shot
on highly detailed sets, visual effects and [CGI](/wiki/Computer-
generated_imagery "Computer-generated imagery") was incorporated in post-
production to enhance the imagery for the scenes that were impossible to shoot
in live action.[62]

The effects included the creation of interior architecture, backgrounds, set
extensions and war weapons; changes to lighting and time of day, weather
effects and the multiplication of army soldiers.[66][62] The opening night-
time war scene, which had 300 visual effects shots, was [filmed in bright
daylight](/wiki/Day_for_night "Day for night") then converted into night.[38]
Arrows flying over the battlefield were created using CGI whereas the army,
soldiers and horses were multiplied. The war close-up shots were filmed in a
studio but were later mixed with the war scenes to form a detailed scene.[62]
In some shots, the sky was digitally replaced and CGI forts were added in
others.[38][46] Similarly, the climax sequence, which was shot live in water,
was enhanced using CGI horses, arrows and fireballs. The climax scene took
around twenty days to complete with fine details.[62]

Bhansali wanted a grand opening title design, which the team decided to create
using animation.[62] They crafted hand-drawn storyboards and drew a narration
of Bajirao and his kingdom, and designed it digitally using animation within a
limited timeline.[62] A sequence in which Singh crosses the sea in a boat at
night was created using visual effects. Splashing waves, falling rain falling
(except for the water falling on Singh and the night sky were created in post
production.[62] The scenes that were shot on set and featured outside views,
such as views from windows, were completed in post production.[46] For dark,
emotional scenes, a low-key background was created, whereas bright, colourful
backgrounds were created with effects for light scenes.[62] The film was
edited by Rajesh G. Pandey.[3]

## Soundtrack[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Soundtrack")]

Main article: [Bajirao Mastani
(soundtrack)](/wiki/Bajirao_Mastani_\(soundtrack\) "Bajirao Mastani
\(soundtrack\)")

The [original score](/wiki/Film_score "Film score") of the film was composed
by [Sanchit Balhara](/wiki/Sanchit_Balhara "Sanchit Balhara") and the
soundtrack album was composed by Bhansali.[67] The lyrics are written by
Siddharth–Garima, [A. M. Turaz](/wiki/A._M._Turaz "A. M. Turaz") and Prashant
Ingole.[67] The album consists of ten original songs with vocals by [Shreya
Ghoshal](/wiki/Shreya_Ghoshal "Shreya Ghoshal"), [Arijit
Singh](/wiki/Arijit_Singh "Arijit Singh"), [Vishal
Dadlani](/wiki/Vishal_Dadlani "Vishal Dadlani"), Shashi Suman, Kunal Pandit,
Prithvi Gandharva, Kanika Joshi, Rashi Raagga, Geetikka Manjrekar, Payal Dev,
Shreyas Puranik, [Vaishali Mhade](/wiki/Vaishali_Mhade "Vaishali Mhade"),
[Javed Bashir](/wiki/Javed_Bashir "Javed Bashir"), Ganesh Chandanshive and
[Sukhwinder Singh](/wiki/Sukhwinder_Singh "Sukhwinder Singh").[67] The
soundtrack was released by [Eros Music](/wiki/Eros_International "Eros
International") on 24 November 2015.[68]

The soundtrack album was well received by music critics, who praised the
soulful compositions and called them "melodious and fresh".[67] R.M. Vijayakar
of _[India-West](/w/index.php?title=India-West&action=edit&redlink=1 "India-
West \(page does not exist\)")_ gave the album 4.5 out of 5, calling it
"unforgettable" and complimented the use of musical instruments and
orchestration, noting portions of the score as the most significant
standout.[69] _[Firstpost](/wiki/Firstpost "Firstpost")_ gave a highly
positive review, praising the "elegantly arranged and opulently orchestrated"
songs and writing, "exhilarating soundtrack ... recreates an era gone-by
through sounds that are authentic ... yet operatic, steeped in the classical
ethos, yet contemporary".[70] Joginder Tuteja of [Bollywood
Hungama](/wiki/Bollywood_Hungama "Bollywood Hungama") gave a rating of 3.5 out
of 5, calling it "high on classical base" and saying half of the compositions
were situational and narrative-based that can "be expected to make a good
impression on screen".[67] _[The Indian Express](/wiki/The_Indian_Express "The
Indian Express")_ also gave it a 3.5 out of 5, noting its distinct sound and
its "balance between restraint and exuberance" and wrote, "_Bajirao Mastani_
sounds fresh, like carefully restored music from Bajirao's times".[71]

## Marketing and
release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Marketing and release")]

_Bajirao Mastani_ was one of the most anticipated releases of 2015. Special
care was taken to avoid leaks during production; everything was done in
secrecy.[72] On 15 July 2015, a day before the teaser release, producers Eros
International shared the first images of the three characters and a teaser
poster of the film.[73] The three-minute teaser trailer, with only one line of
dialogue, was released on 16 July 2015.[74] The teaser garnered high praise
from all quarters and was deemed "grand" and "epic".[74][75][76] [CNN-
News18](/wiki/CNN-News18 "CNN-News18") called the teaser "regal, grand and
breathtaking", and wrote that it had all the signature Bhansali elements such
as "the big sets, larger than life characters, lots of colours and a tragic
love story in the midst of all this grandeur".[76] _[India
Today](/wiki/India_Today "India Today")_ wrote, "With its royal canvas,
_Bajirao Mastani_ teaser is a burst of colours and action reminiscent of the
18th century".[74] In early November 2015, characters posters of the three
characters were also unveiled.[77][_[unreliable
source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Identifying
reliable sources")_][78][79][_[unreliable
source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Identifying
reliable sources")_] The trailer was released on 20 November 2015 and was also
well received.[80]

As a part of the promotions, a multi-episode [graphic web
series](/wiki/Graphic_novel "Graphic novel") –India's first – titled _Blazing
Bajirao_ was released digitally in November 2015.[81][82] Featuring the
animated [avatars](/wiki/Avatar "Avatar") of Bajirao, Kashibai and Mastani,
the graphic series narrates the tales of Bajirao's heroism and his
relationship with his two wives.[81][82] This was followed by a video game
titled _Blazing Bajirao – The Game_ the next month.[83] Released on the [App
Store](/wiki/App_Store_\(iOS\) "App Store \(iOS\)") and [Google
Play](/wiki/Google_Play "Google Play"), the interactive game requires its
players to fight enemies as Peshwa Bajirao.[83] A multi-city press tour, which
saw Singh and Padukone visiting several cities, was designed to promote the
film.[84] Chopra, who could not be in India for the promotions as she was
filming for _Quantico_ , promoted the film in the United States at a press
conference in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City").[85]

Even before its release and without watching the film, the descendants of
Bajirao, Mastani and Kashiabi expressed their disapproval of "Malhari" and
"Pinga" dance sequences, the midriff-baring saris worn by Kashibai and Mastani
in the song "Pinga", a dialogue deeming it "vulgar" and a "private moment"
shown in the trailer, claiming excessive creative liberty was taken by the
director.[86][87] Though not against the release of the film, the descendants
publicly asked the makers to remove those two songs and screen the film for
them so they could review and suggest Bhansali remove other "objectionable
content" from the film.[88] Bhansali did not respond.[87] Additionally, a
petition was filed by an activist in [Bombay High
Court](/wiki/Bombay_High_Court "Bombay High Court") seeking stay on the film
for the two aforementioned songs, accusing it of "distorting history"; the
High Court rejected the petition and refused to interfere with the film's
release.[89]

One of the [most expensive Hindi films ever
made](/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_Indian_films "List of most expensive Indian
films"), _Bajirao Mastani_ cost ₹1.25 billion to make and an additional ₹200
million for marketing and advertisements; its total budget was ₹1.45
billion.[2][90][91] Even before its release, the film recovered almost all of
its production costs – ₹1.20 billion – from sales of its satellite rights,
[music rights](/wiki/Music_licensing "Music licensing") and overseas rights
being sold for ₹500 million and ₹700 million, respectively.[92][_[unreliable
source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Identifying
reliable sources")_] The film was released on 18 December 2015 on 2,700
screens worldwide.[2] Although the makers had booked the date a year in
advance, the makers of _[Dilwale](/wiki/Dilwale_\(2015_film\) "Dilwale \(2015
film\)")_ decided to release their film on the same date, causing a highly
publicised clash between the two films.[93][94] _Bajirao Mastani_ had to share
the 5,000 domestic screens with _Dilwale_ in a 40:60 ratio.[95]

Distributed by [Eros Home Video](/wiki/Eros_International "Eros
International"), the film was released on [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") and [Blu-
ray](/wiki/Blu-ray "Blu-ray") on 18 March 2016.[96][97] The DVD version was
released in all [regions](/wiki/DVD_region_code "DVD region code") as a two-
disc pack in [NTSC](/wiki/NTSC "NTSC") widescreen format; bonus content
included documentaries about the [making of the film](/wiki/Making-of "Making-
of"), its sets, costumes, music, movie images and deleted scenes.[96] A
[VCD](/wiki/Video_CD "Video CD") version was released at the same time.[98]
The film was also released digitally on platforms such as
[iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes").[99] It is also available on the company's
streaming service [Eros Now](/wiki/Eros_Now "Eros Now").[100] _Bajirao
Mastani_ had its world television premiere on 23 April 2016 on
[Colors](/wiki/Colors_\(TV_channel\) "Colors \(TV channel\)").[101]

## Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Critical response")]

_Bajirao Mastani_ received positive critical feedback.[95] Writing for
_Firstpost_ , [Subhash K. Jha](/wiki/Subhash_K._Jha "Subhash K. Jha") gave it
five stars out of five, calling it a "masterpiece", and comparing it
favourably with _[Mughal-e-Azam](/wiki/Mughal-e-Azam "Mughal-e-Azam")_.[102]
[Anupama Chopra](/wiki/Anupama_Chopra "Anupama Chopra") from _[Hindustan
Times](/wiki/Hindustan_Times "Hindustan Times")_ gave four stars out of five,
terming it "soaring, searing and visually sumptuous", and writing, "_Bajirao
Mastani_ plays out a like an operatic, swooning, feverish love poem". She
praised Singh for "combin[ing] towering strength with aching vulnerability and
helplessness", Chopra for having the "maximum impact" despite fewer scenes,
and called Padukone "riveting".[103] _[The Times of
India](/wiki/The_Times_of_India "The Times of India")_ also gave four stars
out of five, pointing out its "outstanding" cinematography and writing, "Every
visual resembles a grand painting – courts with shadows and chandeliers,
courtiers with tilaks and teers, chambers gleaming with mirrors, skies
blushing with passion".[104]

[Taran Adarsh](/wiki/Taran_Adarsh "Taran Adarsh") from Bollywood Hungama gave
four stars out of five, describing it as "a cinematic gem", and wrote that
"fascinating characters and inspirational sub-plots [in the film] advances
into a stunning culmination".[105] [Zee News](/wiki/Zee_News "Zee News") also
gave four stars out of five and said, "An outright outshining piece of art
made unblemished, sprinkled with sincerity and discipline of acting – this
love folklore will restore the drama lovers, back in their ‘expectation’
block".[106] Shubha Shetty-Saha of _[Mid Day](/wiki/Mid_Day "Mid Day")_ gave
three and a half stars out of five, and wrote, "Sanjay Leela Bhansali in his
characteristic style narrates his version of the story in a Mughal-e-azamesque
scale of grandiosity, replete with breathtakingly beautiful sets, elaborate
and well thought of costumes and accessories and dreamy cinematography", which
transports the viewers to an "unique and stunningly beautiful world".[107]
Ananya Bhattacharya of _[India Today](/wiki/India_Today "India Today")_ also
rated the film three and a half stars out of five, calling it "an experience",
and Bhansali "a master love-storyteller". She praised the performance, saying,
"Ranveer, Deepika, Priyanka shine ... while Tanvi Azmi plays the intimidating
matriarch with elan"; thought she thought the editing "could have been much
crisper".[108]

Writing for [NDTV](/wiki/NDTV "NDTV"), Saibal Chatterjee gave the film three
and a half stars out of five, and said, "There isn't a dull moment in this
colourful and dramatic film that embraces excess with unabashed abandon".[109]
Giving a rating of three stars out of five, [Rajeev
Masand](/wiki/Rajeev_Masand "Rajeev Masand") described the film as "artistic
but exhausting" and was critical of the film's length. He praised the
cinematography, production design and performances; he credited Chopra for
bringing "grace to the character, and practically steal[ing] the film",
Padukone for bringing "heft" to her fight scenes, and Singh for finding his
character's hidden vulnerabilities.[110]

Namrata Joshi of _[The Hindu](/wiki/The_Hindu "The Hindu")_ called the film a
“historical leap”, and wrote, "Sanjay Leela Bhansali returns with another
visual spectacle that wilfully takes liberties with the past that it depicts.
But it does manage to engage even as it exhausts."[111] Conversely, Raja Sen
of [Rediff.com](/wiki/Rediff.com "Rediff.com") was unimpressed with the film
for favouring visual splendour over storyline, rating it two stars out of
five. He praised Singh and Chopra, but disliked Padukone's performance.[112]
Shubhra Gupta of _The Indian Express_ was also disappointed with the film,
writing, "_Bajirao Mastani_ had the potential to be a terrific historical. You
want to be transported. What it ends up being is a costume drama: too many
costumes, too much revved-up, empty drama, and too little plot."[113]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Box office")]

_Bajirao Mastani_ was a major commercial success, grossing over ₹2.55 billion
in India and over ₹1.02 billion in the overseas market for a worldwide box
office gross of over ₹3.56 billion.[2][114] The overseas collections comprised
earnings from five major markets; United States and Canada, United Kingdom,
Middle-east, Australia and the rest of the world; with earnings of ₹440
million, ₹138 million, ₹202 million, ₹57 million and ₹185 million,
respectively.[114] As of September 2017, it is the [fourth-highest-grossing
Bollywood film of 2015](/wiki/List_of_Bollywood_films_of_2015 "List of
Bollywood films of 2015"), the third-highest-grossing Bollywood film in
overseas markets in 2015, the ninth-highest-grossing Bollywood film and one of
the [highest-grossing Indian films](/wiki/List_of_highest-
grossing_Indian_films "List of highest-grossing Indian films") of all
time.[115][116][117]

The film collected ₹128 million nett on its opening day, which was the tenth-
highest of the year.[118][_[unreliable
source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Identifying
reliable sources")_] On its second day the film saw growth in its collection
as it collected ₹155.2 million nett.[119] The film showed further growth on
its third day as it collected ₹184.5 million nett to take its first weekend
total to ₹467.7 million nett.[120] In its opening weekend, the film debuted at
number 10 at the U.S. box office and at number 7 at the UK box
office.[95][121] The film's worldwide opening weekend earning was over ₹915
million.[2] The film remained very strong on its first Monday, dropping by
only 15% and earning ₹102.5 million nett.[122][_[unreliable
source?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources "Wikipedia:Identifying
reliable sources")_]

The film maintained its strong box office run on weekdays.[123] _Bajirao
Mastani_ earned ₹843.6 million nett in the first week at the domestic box
office, while the first-week worldwide collections were over ₹1.6
billion.[2][124] Its first week domestic collection was the fourth-highest of
the year.[125] Revenues grew nearly 20% on its second Friday, earning ₹125
million nett.[126] The film earned over ₹311 billion in its second weekend and
collected a further ₹52.5 million on the second Monday for an eleven-day
domestic total of ₹1.41 billion nett.[127] In the second week, the film earned
approximately ₹552 million.[128] The film registered the fourth-highest third-
week collections of all time, earning a ₹270 million.[129] After its fourth
week collection of ₹70 million, the film's domestic earnings stood at ₹1.75
billion nett.[130] In its fifth weekend, the film continued to perform well in
India, with the best fifth-weekend collections of all the 2015 releases.[131]

### Accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Accolades")]

Main article: [List of accolades received by Bajirao
Mastani](/wiki/List_of_accolades_received_by_Bajirao_Mastani "List of
accolades received by Bajirao Mastani")

_Bajirao Mastani_ received five nominations at the [10th Asian Film
Awards](/wiki/10th_Asian_Film_Awards "10th Asian Film Awards"), including
[Best Film](/wiki/Asian_Film_Award_for_Best_Film "Asian Film Award for Best
Film"), and won the award for Best Special Effects.[132] At the [63rd National
Film Awards](/wiki/63rd_National_Film_Awards "63rd National Film Awards"),
_Bajirao Mastani_ received seven awards, including [Best
Director](/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Direction "National Film Award
for Best Direction") for Bhansali, [Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "National Film
Award for Best Supporting Actress") for Azmi, [Best
Cinematography](/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Cinematography "National
Film Award for Best Cinematography") for Chatterjee, and [Best Art
Direction](/wiki/National_Film_Award_for_Best_Art_Direction "National Film
Award for Best Art Direction").[133] It received fourteen nominations at the
[61st Filmfare Awards](/wiki/61st_Filmfare_Awards "61st Filmfare Awards"); the
most awards for any film that year. _Bajirao Mastani_ went on to win nine
awards, more than any other film at the ceremony,[134] including [Best
Film](/wiki/Filmfare_Award_for_Best_Film "Filmfare Award for Best Film"),
[Best Director](/wiki/Filmfare_Award_for_Best_Director "Filmfare Award for
Best Director") for Bhansali, [Best Actor](/wiki/Filmfare_Award_for_Best_Actor
"Filmfare Award for Best Actor") for Singh, and [Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/Filmfare_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "Filmfare Award for
Best Supporting Actress") for Chopra.[135][136][137] _Bajirao Mastani_
received thirteen nominations at the 22nd [Screen Awards](/wiki/Screen_Awards
"Screen Awards"), including [Best Film](/wiki/Screen_Award_for_Best_Film
"Screen Award for Best Film"), and [Best
Director](/wiki/Screen_Award_for_Best_Director "Screen Award for Best
Director") for Bhansali, and won seven including [Best
Actor](/wiki/Screen_Award_for_Best_Actor "Screen Award for Best Actor") for
Singh, and [Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/Screen_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "Screen Award for Best
Supporting Actress") for Chopra.[138] It also won a leading thirteen awards
(from seventeen nominations) at the [17th IIFA Awards](/wiki/17th_IIFA_Awards
"17th IIFA Awards") including [Best
Director](/wiki/IIFA_Award_for_Best_Director "IIFA Award for Best Director")
for Bhansali, [Best Actor](/wiki/IIFA_Award_for_Best_Actor "IIFA Award for
Best Actor") for Singh, and [Best Supporting
Actress](/wiki/IIFA_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actress "IIFA Award for Best
Supporting Actress") for Chopra.[139][140][141]

## Historical
inaccuracies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bajirao_Mastani&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Historical inaccuracies")]

The film was adapted from the novel _Raau_ , whose accuracy has long been
questioned.[87][142] Bhansali consulted historian [Ninad
Bedekar](/wiki/Ninad_Bedekar "Ninad Bedekar"), who is regarded as an authority
on the Peshwas.[88] According to an article published by
_[Quartz](/wiki/Quartz_\(publication\) "Quartz \(publication\)")_ , the "love
story" of Bajirao and Mastani is "almost entirely fictional", writing that
even the most reliable sources do not give details about the nature of their
relationship.[88] There has been controversy over Mastani's true lineage; two
accounts of Mastani exist– one which says she was a courtesan and Bajirao's
mistress or concubine, and another that is depicted in the film.[143]

According to historian Saili Palande-Datar, very little is known about the
women of that era due to the [orthodoxy](/wiki/Orthodoxy "Orthodoxy"); women
were not given many privileges and rights, and most of the sources from that
period are accounts of political battles, revenues and socio-economic
records.[88] Palande-Datar also said there is no evidence of the way Bajirao
and Mastani's political marriage became part of folklore and was later
transformed into a symbolic representation of great romance.[88] Historian
Prachi Deshpande notes in her book _Creative Pasts: Historical Memory and
Identity in Western India, 1700–1960_ , that the public fascination started
after their romanticisation began in the 1890s, more than 150 years after they
had died, after Marathi playwrights began writing a series of nationalistic
plays based on the historical figures. The first such play that portrayed them
as a [star crossed](/wiki/Star-crossed "Star-crossed") couple was _Bajirao-
Mastani_ (1892) by N B Kanitkar.[88] _Quartz_ also said the play portrayed
them as star crossed lovers and others playwrights followed Kantikar, making
it as familiar to Marathi audiences as that of other epic romances.[88] By the
1930s, a number of historical novels that also added to the "myth-making" were
written, fascinating another generation.[88] The film gives a more of a
personal account of Bajirao's life, which is hard to prove since it has not
been covered much by the historians.[142] Bhansali has said it was his
interpretation of how Bajirao was in his home and in personal life, and there
was no way to know that.[142]

Because of this lack of information, Bhansali took liberties with historical
facts and exaggerated a few things for cinematic effects.[88][142] A
disclaimer on the film's credits stated it does not claim to be historically
accurate.[144] The dance sequences have been widely seen as "fictional" and
"out of place" in historical context.[145] Bajirao's dance sequence in
"Malhari" has been criticised, saying a chief minister such as Bajirao would
never dance in public.[146] Similarly, the "Pinga" dance sequence between
Kashibai and Mastani has been deemed "inappropriate" for women of that
era.[86]

Some historians have said that apart from the inappropriateness of a woman of
Kashiabi's stature dancing in public, she suffered from a type of
[arthritis](/wiki/Arthritis "Arthritis") and that dancing was not physically
possible for her.[146] While some historians have claimed both women met
socially only once; others have said they never met at all.[146] Mastani was
put under [house arrest](/wiki/House_arrest "House arrest") by Balaji while
Bajirao was on military campaign, as opposed to film's depiction of Mastani's
imprisonment. The film shows Bajirao and Mastani dying at the same time in
different places, which did not happen in reality.[143] Bajirao died a few
days earlier than Mastani; however the cause of her death is not known. Some
have claimed she died from shock; other accounts say she committed suicide.
The film portrays Mastani being chained at the time of her death but she was
never chained and she and Kashibai were both present at Bajirao's last
rites.[143][145] After the death of Mastani, Kashibai raised Mastani's son as
her own, which is not shown in the film.[145] Other inaccuracies include
Mastani playing a [mandolin](/wiki/Mandolin "Mandolin"), an instrument that
originated in Europe during the 19th century.[144]
